Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, I hear we have a new heading! Do we have a new assignment?
Well... not exactly. I've actually arranged for us to take a... vacation.
A vacation!? That's fantastic news!
Isn't it? It's a rare opportunity. We won't be entirely off duty - should a Morgana show herself, we'll still be expected to engage. But we'll have plenty of free time to take advantage of.
And where are we taking advantage of this free time exactly?

Fields.MenuText: Where do you think?
I'm not sure I want to ruin the surprise.
Somewhere you'll enjoy, trust me.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmmm... I'm not sure. There are too many possibilities.
Well, I'm sure you should. So tell me, hehe.
I want to trust you... but I also want to know.
You'll find out soon enough. Trust me, it's somewhere you'll love.
*ALARM*
You think the Morganas might take a vacation while we're on vacation?
Unlikely.
Well, let's try to convince them otherwise.
Phew, she bought it. Hopefully she'll be able to just enjoy her vacation for as long as possible.
@BATTLE
Are we going to a foreign land to do all the touristy things?
Are we going to dive for buried treasure?
Oh, are we going to a mountain resort to go skiing down the slopes?

Fields.MenuText: You're a ship. How would you get up a mountain?
Yep, you got it, Dunkerque. Well done.
Stop guessing already!

Fields.DialogueText: I've already thought about that. We'd need to find a geyser.
Really?
Ooh, that got a reaction out of you! I must be getting close.
Even if you get it right, I'm not going to tell you.
But why not? I want to know. Tell me. S'il vous plaît?
You don't like surprises?
Non, surprises can be fun. But sometimes, it's more fun to know things. So tell me.
Dîtes-moi! Come Capitaine you must tell me!
*ALARM*
Thank goodness.
@BATTLE
Clearly you're just teasing mean! I'll have to keep guessing!
Okay, Capitaine, are we going to...
I'm going to stop you right there. If you keep guessing, I'm going to actually tell you.
Merveilleuse! That's exactly what I want.
That would completely ruin the surprise of it, though. Is that really what you want?
Hmmm... well. I... I think I want to know. Are you trying to confuse me, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: I would never dream of it.
That depends. Is it working?
Oh, I'm just going to tell you. We're going to...

Fields.DialogueText: Bien, you would have to wake quite early to fool me Captiaine!
No. I... I still want to know... I'm mostly sure of it.
No, stop! I need to think about this for a second.
Will knowing the surprise make me even happier than I am now?
There's only one way to find out.
No, wait! Okay, I'm going to trust you. Keep your surprise.
*ALARM*
You made your choice just in time.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, there are Morganas on the horizon.
*ALARM
@BATTLE
Dunkerque, I hope you're ready to be shocked and amazed.
Oh? Are we here? Is it surprise time?
We're finally here.
This moment has been built up in my head for so long. I hope it lives up to my expectations. I'd hate to be disappointed.

Fields.MenuText: You're not going to be disappointed.
Why do you think you'd be disappointed?
Don't worry yourself, Dunkerque.

Fields.DialogueText: You sound really certain. I hope you know me as well as you think you do.
Well, it's like being promised the best birthday present ever, only, it's a dog and you're allergic. It's a big let down.
I'm not worried, I'm just... concerned you brought me to... a library or something.
Dunkerque, just come with me to the deck. I promise, what you see will make you smile.
All right... let's go. I hope this surprise really is as wonderful as you think it is.
Well, you tell me. What do you think?
I think we might just be a little too close to land, Capitaine.
That's the point. How else are you going to be able to enjoy the beach?
Quoi?! You mean this was the surprise? A beach trip?!
Happy?
En extase! You really do know me, Capitaine! Give me a second, I just need to go get all my things.
Dunkerque, aren't you ready yet?
I would have been ready had someone given me proper warning.

Fields.MenuText: You liked the surprise.
Well, excuse me. I won't make that mistake again.
If I had known you'd take this long to get ready, I would have given you a few weeks' notice.

Fields.DialogueText: It was a very nice surprise. Thank you.
No, I liked it. You're pretty good at surprises.
You'll be thanking me later when my preparations come in handy.
All right, I think I'm just about ready.
You're bringing a basket full of... what is all that stuff?
Well, let's see here. A few beach towels, some spare clothing, extra ammunition, and all of my beauty supplies.
Shells, makeup, and beach towels? That's certainly a variety.
I'm prepared for anything.
*ALARM*
Anything?
What do you think the ammunition is for?
@BATTLE
This is wonderful, Capitaine. Sunbathing on the beach is such a different experience from laying on the deck.
I wouldn't know. The deck is for working, not relaxing.
I know that, but sometimes the weather is just so nice. It's important to enjoy it.

Fields.MenuText: I will admit, it's pretty nice to take a break like this.
There will be plenty of time to enjoy the weather when the Morganas are gone.
I wish I could, but I'm the captain. I'm a little too busy to take time off.

Fields.DialogueText: Bien sûr! And this is just the start of our beach activities!
Don't be like that. If we can't live our lives while the Morganas are here, then they might as well have already won.
I didn't realise you were so weighed down with responsibilities. Maybe I should help out more around the ship to take some of that weight off your shoulders.
I'm starting to think, more and more, that we really needed some time to lay in the sun.
Maybe you're right. Everyone certainly looks like they're enjoying themselves.
Mmmm, I certainly am...
It's just... It's hard to get a tan when there's a battleship blocking the sun.
You do have quite an impressive shadow, don't you?
Pft, I just wish we could've just dropped anchor a little further away.
The only way you can relax on the beach is if the ship is close by. Plus, this way, we can keep an ear out for the alarm.
I know, I know. A girl can wish, though.
*ALARM*
And Morganas can attack that girl while she's busy wishing in the sun.
Should I leave the towels here, or...?
We'll be back soon enough.
Good! I'll just grab my extra ammo then.
@BATTLE
Enjoying some volleyball, Dunkerque?
Phew, it's beach volleyball. The beach makes it more fun!
I can see that. You're not running the crew too ragged, are you?
Nah, they're doing great. They've had me giving it my all. I can't wait for the next game.

Fields.MenuText: They look pretty exhausted to me. Maybe you should go a little easy on them.
Is it really that fun? I've never played before.
How have you hardly broken a sweat? You were running and jumping all over the place.

Fields.DialogueText: Never. It's no fun if everyone isn't trying their best!
You've never played?! How is that possible? Were you raised in a bunker?
I'm working up a sweat. I'm just having too much fun to get tired!
You should join us for the next game, Capitaine! You'd be a welcome addition.
I'm not sure about that...
Nonsense! Okay, everyone, the capitaine is joining us! Get ready for the next match!
*ALARM*
Dammit, nevermind!
I'm sure you can start your next game after we've finished with these Morganas, okay?
I think you mean, you're sure we can start our next game after we've finished with these Morganas. Right?
@BATTLE
How do you like my sand castle, Capitaine? The seashell ornamentation gives it a certain je ne sais quoi, don't you think?

Fields.MenuText: You don't think the moat is a little much?
It's really well made. You certainly put a lot of effort into it.
How did you do that? Did you bring extra tools or something? Is this some sort of Belle trick?

Fields.DialogueText: How else am I supposed to protect all the little sand citizens from the tide?
Thank you. I tried to make the castle I'd want to live in. You know, if a battleship could fit in a castle.
Just a shovel and pail! I have a knack for this, I think.
How's your castle looking?
Not nearly as impressive as yours.
Oh, it's cute. I like it. It's very you, Capitaine.
What's that supposed to mean?
Ha! Nothing, of course.
Capitaine, I'm so happy we've had this opportunity. It's been such a nice little vacation in amongst all the fighting.
I'm glad you're enjoying yourself. I'm sure the coming days will be just as pleasant.
Yeah, it's... huh. How long is this vacation going to last, Capitaine?
What do you mean?
We've been out here for a while. As much as I've been enjoying myself... surely we have to get back to the fighting soon, right?
*ALARM*
Ummm, see? Right there. A fight is headed our way.
I get the feeling you're not telling me something, Capitaine.
All I have to say is that we need to go protect our sand castles from the Morgana menace. Let's go.
@BATTLE
These... buckets are... heavier than I thought they'd be.
Dunkerque, what are those buckets full of? Are those crabs?
Mhmmm. I went shellfish diving! Guess what we're having for dinner tonight.

Fields.MenuText: Crab sounds pretty good, I'll admit.
I was actually hoping for something sweeter today. Maybe Ice cream.
I can't stand shellfish, so I can tell you what I'm not eating.

Fields.DialogueText: Great! Oh, and we can have a beach bonfire and cook them up like that! We can make a whole night of it!
Ice cream for dinner? You're mad, Capitaine. But you know what would be even crazier? Both ice cream and crab for dinner.
Then what did I catch all these guys for? I hope the crew will enjoy them, at least.
All this talk of food is making me hungry. It might be mealtime already.
Sure, and while we're eating, you can tell me all about how you talked your way into this vacation.
That sounds like a boring conversation to me.
Oh, come on, Capitaine. I want to know how you managed to get us shore leave at a time like this. Not that I'm not thankful. I'm just curious.
*ALARM*
Can it really be considered shore leave when we have to constantly drop what we're doing and fight hordes of Morganas?
Damn Morganas. Always showing up when it's most inconvenient.
... Inconvenient for you, maybe.
What was that? Did you say something?!
@BATTLE
You want to do what to me?
Oh, come on, it'll be fun. Just let me bury you up to your neck.
Uh, I don't think so. That sounds like a surefire way to find myself trapped against my will.
Dammit, you figured out my plan.
Were you planning to do something to me once I was buried, Dunkerque?
Maybe...

Fields.MenuText: Were you going to paint my face like a clown?
Were you going to bash my head in then bury me completely?! What did I ever do to you?!
You were going to feed me leftover crab, weren't you?

Fields.DialogueText: Heh, that would've been funny, but no.
That escalated quickly! You should know me better than that, Capitaine!
Your aversion to shellfish is a little strange, Capitaine.
I was just going to make you tell me how this vacation of ours came about.
You really dislike not knowing things, don't you?
I guess. It just irritates me when I know you're not telling me something.
Well... there is something I've been meaning to tell you, Dunkerque.
Oh? You have something you want to tell me? Um... right here and now?
This isn't really a vacation.
Huh? Oh, that's not what I thought you were gonna say.
Word of your defeat in the yacht race has been spreading. It's a ridiculous reason, but you've been removed from the front lines because of... bad press.
What? But... I only lost because I was fighting Morganas.
I know. It's politics, I'm afraid. And as a result, we've been assigned patrol out here. The views are beautiful, but the threats are... lacking.
*ALARM*
Perfect timing. I feel like I need to shoot something.
That could've gone worse, I suppose.
@BATTLE
Dunkerque, why aren't you out on the beach?
The beach doesn't seem as fun anymore. Why did you have to tell me such horrible news at such a nice place?

Fields.MenuText: I was hoping it wouldn't seem so bad if you were having fun.
I guess I wasn't thinking.
Excuse me, but I seem to remember you forcing me to tell you.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, next time, just rip the bandage off. If you had done that, you could've cheered me up at the beach.
I suppose I shouldn't have expected you to think before acting. It would've been out of character.
Really? All I remember is heartbreak.
I'm sorry... I think I may be getting a little dramatic. I just can't believe that Command doesn't want me fighting Morganas on the front lines because I lost a silly race.
A race with some of the most influential gossips I've ever met.
This is the worst!
You're right. It is. So... how about we do something about it?
What do you mean?
Why don't we show everyone that those rumors are wrong? Let's do something that proves to Command how capable we are.
You mean, do something to repair our reputation?
Exactly. You're an amazing Belle. We have a capable crew. It shouldn't be too hard to make everyone else see that again.
*ALARM*
I wish fighting bad press was as easy as fighting Morganas.
@BATTLE
Ouch.
All right, Capitaine, J'en ai fini de m'apitoyer sur mon sort. I'm done pitying myself. I think you were right.

Fields.MenuText: I'm right about so many things. You're going to have to be more specific.
I'm glad you're cheering up, but I'm even happier that you're seeing things my way.
About proving ourselves? Or did I say some other brilliant thing that I'm forgetting?

Fields.DialogueText: About showing the higher ups that they shouldn't listen to rumors.
What can I say? You have good ideas. Sometimes.
Yes, about proving ourselves. I'm glad you didn't already forget.
Well then, I think it's about time we got under weigh.
Not so fast. I mean, we're not going to have shore leave like this again anytime soon. I think we should take advantage of it.
What do you have in mind?
Une fête bien sûr! A party! A little soirée to end our vacation properly.
That's a plan I can get behind! Maybe we could roast a pig?
Barbacue? Magnifique Capitaine! I've always wanted to try that!
@BATTLE
Well Dunkerque, you certainly know how to throw a party.
I do, don't I? Everyone looks like they're having a great time.

Fields.MenuText: I'm just worried about that bonfire getting out of control,
I just hope those guys smashing watermelons don't start smashing anything else.
I think I might've seen a few of the officers getting a little too friendly with each other. Where's a chaperone when you need one?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, don't worry, the ocean is right there!
They're not going to escalate from watermelons to kneecaps. Relax, Capitaine.
Let them have their fun. There's no harm with a little fraternization, right? At least, I hope not, heh.
I'm just glad everyone's having one last great bash.
What about you? I hope I didn't ruin the beach for you with the bad news.
No, you could never ruin anything for me, Capitaine. The time we've spent together has been really fun. But unfortunately, we have a job to do.
Unfortunately? Would you rather spend your life here on this beach?
Hmmm... maybe if you were here with me.
*ALARM*
And there weren't Morganas around to interrupt all my parties.
They're upset they weren't sent an invitation.
@BATTLE
Réveillez-vous, mon choux. Time to wake up, Capitaine - we need to get under way!
Ugggh, don't talk so loud. Wait... what was that last word? Cabbage?
You must have misheard me. I think you may have celebrated the end of our vacation a tad enthusiastically Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: No, I just have this... horrible, inexplicable headache.
Maybe, but you're the one who kept refilling my drinks.
I vaguely remember dancing... did I at least have all my clothes on?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh bien sûr, completely  inexplicable. Whatever you say, Capitaine.
Hmmm? It's almost like I was trying to get you drunk or something, heh.
No. But don't worry, you weren't the only one. You started a trend.
All right... I'm just going to pretend like last night never happened.
I'm not. It was too much fun. Besides you were wonderful dance partner.
We danced? Now that I wish I could remember. How's the crew? Will we be ready to leave on schedule?
Everyone's moving a little slower than they usually do, but I think we'll be ready. You know, I miss this beach already.
Still. We danced?
Oui, quite a bit. Not to worry I'll refresh your memory. After we get back my good name of course.
Of course. Now let's head out. No time to waste, right?
@BATTLE
Okay... so where exactly should we be heading, Dunkerque?
To... adventure? I don't know. You're the capitaine. Shouldn't you know how to do this?
Typically, we have assignments telling us where we ought to go. This will require a change of thinking on both our parts.
The way I see it, we need to do something that will get us noticed. Something big and important. Something no one has managed to handle yet.

Fields.MenuText: Like ending the war!
Like finding and destroying an especially dangerous Morgana?
Maybe we could challenge those rich snobs to a rematch.

Fields.DialogueText: Okay, maybe we should aim a little lower. Let's be realistic about this, mon choux.
Excellente, Capitaine! We just need to find the foulest of those creatures in these waters.
Tempting to be sure, but even if we beat them, that will likely make them not say anything at all. Few brag of their defeats.
I think we should start by heading to port. If there are any challenges that need to be met, that's where we'll hear about them. Right?
That's... exactly what I'd suggest. I'm impressed and surprised.
You don't have to be surprised. I'm taking this seriously.
I'm proud of you, Dunkerque.
Heh, thanks, it's nothing.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, look toward the south. I think that's a Morgana submarine!
It looks like it. And she seems to have set her sights set on some poor merchant vessel.
Well, we have to hurry in and help, don't we?

Fields.MenuText: Definitely. We can't just watch from the sidelines.
Lead the way, Dunkerque.
Do we have to? I'm sure they can handle it.

Fields.DialogueText: It's time to save the day!
No, you lead the way. You're the capitaine. You know I don't want to lead.
Was that some poor attempt at sarcasm?
*BOOM*
A direct hit! The merchant vessel is taking on water.
The survivors will need our help. There's no time to lose.
And we can chase the Morgana off too!
@BATTLE
It was just a figure of speech.
Thank you, Captain. You arrived just in time.
I wish we could've arrived a little sooner. We might have been able to save your ship.
Yes, that would've been preferable. Though in truth, the real loss is the cargo.
The cargo? Were you carrying something special?
Valuable crates of goods. And we were almost at port too. Oh well, I suppose we should just be thankful we escaped with our lives. Thank you again, Captain.
It was nothing.
Capitaine?
Yes?
Do you notice anything strange about the merchantman?
No I... huh. That weird ring of bubbles... and the ship is just floating. Shouldn't she be at the bottom of the Atlantic?
It seems like the phenomenon in one of the intelligence reports. Suspension. We should investigate, and try to recover their cargo.

Fields.MenuText: What's with the sudden interest in investigating strange phenomena?
I think the risk to the crew we send aboard is pretty dramatic.
I'm sure the Morganas would be thrilled to happen upon us while our attention is fixated on their prize.

Fields.DialogueText: Since I heard there was valuable cargo right in the middle of one of those phenomena.
Perhaps, but just staying here is risky. We stand to gain much from this venture.
Then we'll have double the lookouts on the search for any sign of trouble.
Alright. Make it quick. We'll come along side and get into a position to give the crane access.
Merci Capitaine! I promise, this will be well worth our time, I can feel it!
Capitaine, we've recovered quite a bit of cargo so far! I wonder what's in all of these crates... treasure peut-être? Gold would be nice.

Fields.MenuText: Don't exaggerate too much. You're not salvaging gold doubloons.
So have you been taking notes on the actual phenomena you're supposed to be investigating?
Maybe wait until you've opened the crates before you start celebrating.

Fields.DialogueText: You don't know what's in these crates. ... Though, it's probably something boring like vegetables.
Bien sûr, capitaine! I haven't the slightest idea how they've done it. I've written every thing I've seen down, but I doubt it's going to be much use.
Imagine if all these crates contained giant hunks of gold. Giant, wet hunks of gold!
I'm going head back across, it's quite novel walking someone else's decks for a change... even if the ship is a wreck for all intents.
So the ship couldn't manifest a Belle you think?
Je ne pense pas Capitaine. I don't think so... it's a bit disturbing. The ship should be a wreck. Her spirit has left her. Yet above the waves she rests.
That just put a shiver down my spine. Let's change subjects. How are you going to spend the money from all this salvage?
Spend? Capitaine, we have the merchant crew aboard. This is hardly salvage and it would be wrong to profit off war materials.
That's... that's incredibly kind of you, Dunkerque.
I'm just excited to be able to help, and investigate a new mystery. Even if I'm not getting very far.
And she's gone. I'm not sure about all this, but it's endearing to watch her get all worked up.
And I am proud of her for returning the cargo. I'm sure we could have made a pretty penny had she sold it all at port. The food we could have bought...
Oh, look at that. I shouldn't get tempted myself. I'm the captain.
@BATTLE
It's been a while since we were last at port. Where should we start?
Actually, I think I already have a lead.
Already? We just arrived.
What can I say? I work fast.

Fields.MenuText: You're joking with me, right?
What are you, psychic?
If you already had a lead, why did we come to port in the first place?

Fields.DialogueText: No, I'm completely serious.
Worried Capitaine? Secret thoughts you might not want to share with your lovely Belle?
To resupply?
I overheard one of the merchants we rescued talking about a large Morgana he'd spotted south of here.
Apparently, the ship only encountered the Morgana that sank their ship because they were trying to avoid an even worse threat.
Even worse? How much worse?
Well, he called her the "Swallower of Worlds." Clearly, an exaggeration, but the name does make an impression.
This sounds like the perfect opportunity. We should have your reputation repaired in no time.
That's the hope. Let's give the people something new to talk about.
Right after we resupply.
Obviously. I don't have a death wish, Capitaine, I'm just starting to really enjoy life.
@BATTLE
... Fair enough.
You know, Dunkerque, I'm really impressed with how you've handled all of this.
You... you are? Don't you remember me sulking about on the beach when you first told me the truth of our "vacation"?
That's going to be a difficult image to forget. But you didn't sulk long, and once you were done, you jumped right back to action, ready to reestablish your good name. I'm proud of you.
Thanks, Capitaine. That means a lot to me. Would you... say that makes me a good crew member?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not really sure you qualify as a crew member. You know, since you're a Belle.
No. Not at all.
I don't think there's anyone better, Dunkerque.

Fields.DialogueText: You know what I mean.
What? Really?
You're going to make me blush if you keep that sort of talk up.
Why are you so concerned with being a good crew member all of a sudden? I hope you're not letting those rumors get to you.
No, it's not that, I just...
*ALARM*
They just love ruining the mood, don't they?
Let's make them regret it.
@BATTLE
A single action doesn't define a person as good or bad. There's so much more that goes into it.
Hey, Dunkerque, are you okay?
Yes? Pourquoi? What have you heard?
It's just that all that talk about being a good crew member has been out of character for you. I want to know if something's bothering you.
I just... It's stupid, but I guess I've always been a little worried. Worried that I wasn't cut out for this... line of work.
This line of work? You're going to have to explain a little more.
I've just always had these impulses. I want to be free, to do whatever I want whenever I want. I want to be free to sail where I want, fight where I want, and do whatever I want!
I'm not seeing the issue. You're a free spirit.
That's not the kind of behavior that a crew member should have. That's... that's more like a pirate!

Fields.MenuText: You're afraid of being a pirate?
More like the romanticized view of a pirate.
Is it? Who doesn't like freedom?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, not afraid... I mean, I am, but I'm not. It's confusing.
I mean... you're not wrong.
As members of the fleet, we're under others' authority. We're not free.
I've heard horrible stories about pirates. They raid ships, they destroy ports, they kill people. And yet... they're free.
Does envying that freedom make me a bad person, Capitaine?
Dunkerque, you are far from a bad person. Just because you want to be free doesn't mean you're a pirate.
It doesn't?
Real pirates are certainly free in a sense, but they use their freedom to hurt and prey on others. That's not you. You're a tremendous asset to this crew who constantly supports those around her.
Heh, you sure have a high opinion of me, Capitaine.
The highest opinion. You're one of my favorite people in the world, you know?
... And you're one of mine. In fact, as long as you're here by my side keeping my head straight, I don't think I'll ever have to worry about becoming a pirate.
*ALARM*
You know, the Morganas are more than a little piratical.
We'll show them they're no match for us.
@BATTLE
Hey, Dunkerque, I just...
Garde à vous! Chin up, back straight! Right... uniform is in order... we've not stopped fighting Morgana during our vacaton so why am I nervous?
I have nothing to fear from the foul sea witches. I'm the battleship Dunkerque after all. They haven't a chance once they come under my guns!
Hmph. Getting nervous, really for me to be so silly. With mon choux by my side the Morgen saleté are as good as sunk! Now I should go find Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Ahem.
What a speech! I wish the crew was here to hear it.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Capitaine! How... how long have you been standing there?
Capitaine! You heard that?! You cannot sneak up on a lady like that! Ce n'est tout simplement pas fait! It's just not done!
All right, time to find the Capitaine, track down that Morgana, and take down that ugly escapee from a breaker's yard... oh, Capitaine!
How much did you hear?
Enough. You were having quite the conversation with yourself.
Don't tease me before a battle. I need to prepare myself before going into battle against this supposed monster Morgen.
Sorry, sorry. You look absolutely murderous.
That's better. Did you need something? Or are we ready to cast this sea monster back to the depths?
Actually, we just received a...
*ALARM*
Oh, no, looks like we attracted some attention.
Hmm. Well if we prune some support fleets now it could weaken the local flagship.
Excellent point. Let's go!
@BATTLE
There she is! Those Morgen aircraft carriers never cease to amaze.

Fields.MenuText: Amaze... in a nauseating sort of way, I suppose.
She's a hefty one, all right.
I feel like I'm staring into the abyss...

Fields.DialogueText: I know what you mean... the longer I look at her, the more unsettled I feel.
I'd like to see you say that to her face.
She's kind of... hypnotising, isn't she?
All right! The time for talk is done. Une fois de plus dans la bataille! Once more unto the breach!
Lead the way, Capitaine. I'd follow you anywhere.
... This was your idea.
You're the Capitaine. Lead the way!
@BATTLE
Swallower of Worlds, huh? I think she might've bitten off more than she could chew.
Nice one liner.
Merci! I was thinking about it on the way here.
You think that's going to be enough to convince Command to put me back on the frontlines?
Actually, I had something to show you about that. Here.
Something to show me? A letter?
Read it.
We... have an assignment waiting for us back home? Rumors spread fast!
I don't think they heard about your latest conquest just yet.
Then what's this letter about?
I don't know yet, but I'll ask some questions. For now, just enjoy the fact that... somehow we did it.
Hmph, that will show those puffed up snobs. Try to mess with me will they?
So any news about this letter, Capitaine? I've read it half a dozen times, and it still makes no sense. It's not like Command to change their minds on a whim.
Actually, I asked a contact of mine. Apparently, that merchant vessel we rescued was carrying cargo vital for the continued war effort against the Morganas.
Oh? So we helped without even meaning to?
Exactly. And thanks to us, Command was saved a lot of time and money. That was enough to improve your standing in their eyes.
We should rescue ships more often!
We certainly should. For now, though, are you ready to take a more active role in the INPF?
Hmmm... I'm... I think so... Peut être? Maybe.

Fields.MenuText: You don't sound so sure.
That's good enough for me!
If you're not ready, maybe we should turn down this mission.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm... not.
What? That's shouldn't be good enough for you. I'm clearly torn here.
No! We worked too hard for this. I just...
I just have personal reasons for why I might not be ready to jump back into the action.
Those reasons being?
Well... I really enjoyed spending all this relaxing time with you.
*ALARM*
I'm not sure relaxing is the word I'd use.
Morganas are a small price to pay for spending time with you Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Captain! Morgana ships on the Northern horizon! They're closing fast!
Battle stations.
@BATTLE
It won't be long until we reach port, Dunkerque. This is your last chance to go rogue.
Ha. Ha. Very funny. Don't use my fears as fuel for your jokes.
You're right, I'm sorry.
Capitaine?
Yes, Dunkerque?
What's the INPF's policy for... fraternization?
Of the romantic sort?
... Yes.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure they care.
While I doubt they've had the time to instate a policy, I imagine they wouldn't approve.
As long as battles continue to be won, I don't think they'll complain.

Fields.DialogueText: They don't care? That's good.
Are you sure? That's ridiculous. They shouldn't keep people from falling in love.
Well... I guess that makes sense. Winning the war is the most important thing.
Why do you ask?
Oh, no reason. I was just curious.
Really? Just curious?
Yes. Definitely. I have no plans to ever make use of that information in the future.
You sound very convincing.
Of course I do. I'm an excellent liar, mon choux.
